course.subject: ACCT
course.name: Laws in Society and Business
course.description: This course provides an introduction to law and business society. Topics include general introduction to the concepts in law; an introduction to the Hong Kong legal system under the principle of "one country, two systems"; copyright law; trademark law; agency law; insolvency law; employment law and business ethics. As Hong Kong is a well-developed business society, this course is intended to build students' understanding of the relationship between the law and the society and discuss laws in society and business.

reviews.author: whlian
reviews.title: Nice grade course
reviews.comment_content: Legal system, contracts, employment laws, tort, trademark
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof is really kind and nice, willing to answer students questions and offer Q&A section before each quiz.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade of the course is decent. All the quizzes are open book. Some quiz questions appeared in lec notes before. Remember remember to attend class before quiz! Lots of tips for the tests! Just get some time for memorisation of the lec note and have common sense are fully enough to get a nice result.

Best two quiz grade out of three + individual report + in class writing + participation
reviews.comment_workload:
No MT and final. Only 3 quizes to be tested, and the content for the quizes is not hard and much. But in last semester(zoom class), I needed to submit review per week and I just wrote few sentences on the questions. I think it’s counted in participation, the content is less important than submission.

The major workload for this course is individual writing. The individual report is quite hash if you are a deadline fighter as it requires students to read an original and extremely long legal record before writing. This step takes quite a while to understand the content and analysis. The individual report is given about 1 month time to complete, students are advised to start it ASAP and ask prof whenever you have problem! As once you analysis wrong the stance of the court, you have to redo your whole writing! Be aware of this.

In class writing doesn’t cause any workload but students are advised to have some practise on case reading and revise on legal concepts, as the time given for this task is quite short and it will be hard to finish if you can’t response quick.

reviews.author: JimmyMcgill
reviews.comment_content:
1. Legal system
2. Contract Law
3. Tort Law
4. Business Organisation

The content is hard and abstract. Students are expected to apply concepts learnt in class to solve different business cases.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Tan is kind and patient. She is willing to solve students' problems. Business cases of different topics will be discussed in class and many of them will appear in quizzes. Make sure you don't miss any of the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 quizzes 2*25% (the best two out of three)
individual final report 35%
individual participation 10%
group exercise 5%

Quizzes:
all mc, open book and open note

For individual participation and group exercise, the scores and marking schemes were not transparent. My suggestion is to be more proactive in class so as to perform better in this two areas.

For individual final report, you will need to write a 800-1000 words legal report for either the plaintiff or the defendant of a case. Do spend more time on it and start earlier even though you will be given quite a long time to complete.

I think the grading is lenient.
As a SENG student, didn't really expect to perform well in this course. I got mean for all quizzes and wasn't really active in class. End up getting a B+, which was completely out of my expectation. Perhaps
reviews.comment_workload: No workload at all. But it is quite hard to understand all the concepts and handle some cases as they are quite abstract, be well prepared before quizzes. The final report may also take some time.

reviews.author: wondood
reviews.title: Good grade, nice prof & lots of knowledge
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers a wide range of legal concepts and principles, mostly about business law.
1. introducing legal system in Hong Kong and in the world

2. contract law
- how to form contracts
- distinguishing whether there’s a contract
- evaluating whether the contract is valid
- breach of contract & how to claim remedies

3. IP law
- trademark, patent, copyright

4. Employment law
- what should be included in an employment contract
- employee vs contractor, their differences and advantages / disadvantages

5. Legal writing
- how to do legal writing, assignment about analysing a legal case with the legal principles learned in class

Every topics in this course is interesting and relevant to our daily life, so they’re really worth learning. Each topic is very rich in content, not just a brief introduction, so you could really learn a lot from this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although there’re many information to be taken in, the professor teaches well by illustrating each legal principles with examples and discussion. However, the discussion in breakout room is a bit waste of time as no one actually speak in breakout room.
People has a lot of question for this class, and Professor answered each questions immediately in details. She doesn’t get annoyed for stupid questions so I think she’s a very good and patient prof.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good.

Quiz 1 (17%) : 50/50 (mean 44.1)
Quiz 2 (17%) : 44/50 (mean 41.8)
Quiz 3 (16%) : 96/100 (mean 88.3)
Individual Final Report (30%) : 27.5/30 (mean 24.5)
In-class writing practice (5%) : 4.75/5 (mean 4.3)
Assignments & mini quizzes (10%) : unknown, I missed 3 of them out of 12
Participation (5%) : should be full as long as you speak up a few times

Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Quiz:
- All 3 quizzes are open book, 25 mcq , 50mins
- Quizzes are non-cumulative
- More then 5 questions in the quiz are from the sample quiz provided
So the quiz is very easy and you have lots of time to complete each quiz

2. Mini assignment
- assigned after each class to reflect on one of the sample case mentioned in the lecture
- have a few days to finish it
- Assignment graded on effort (you’ll got mark as long as you submit it)

3. Individual final report
- you’ll be assigned to one of the case as either plaintiff or defendant
- You’re asked to write a case brief, an argument for your position and a possible rebuttal from your opponent
- word limit 600-800
Since the report is just 800 words is it quite easy to complete but required some time to study the case thoroughly to write good analysis

4. In-class writing practise
- You’ll be learning how to do legal writing a class before the in-class practise
It’s a quick and easy practise that asked you to put some legal principles in your reflection. I write quite horribly but still gets good mark.

5. Participation
You definitely have the chances to speak up as long as you want to as she gives a few discussion sections every class. Since law is something arguable, there’s no right or wrong answer, so you don’t need to feel embarrassed for discussing in class.
Just attended the class and speak up a few times and you’ll be fine. No need to open camera.

reviews.author: lcyxd
reviews.comment_content: He started off by teaching The Rule of law, Copyright law, Trademarks law (before midterm), then Insolvency law, Employment Law and Business ethics. The concepts are relatively easy to understand, accompanied by several case studies in every chapter.
reviews.comment_teaching: Charles is very patient and willing to explain all the essentials and will provide a brief review of the previous lesson before every class. However, some might find him a bit repetitive, despite he tries to make the atmosphere relaxing/light. He would mention some of the key concepts and question framework in classes prior to mid-term/final - so make sure you don't skip those classes.
reviews.comment_grading: Includes group research paper and presentation, mid-term and final. Got max for mid-term where the marks for final was not disclosed. Grading for group research paper and presentation is pretty lenient. Final grade: A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Cheatsheet is allowed in exam so you only have to cram everything in and don't have to memorize everything. Yet, attending the lessons really help with the understanding so don't consider skipping lessons that frequent. The group research project could be a bit tough as topics might not too familiar to most business school students.

reviews.author: hlnt9099207420
reviews.comment_content:
Topics learned

*The Rule of law
*Copyright law
*Trademarks law
*Insolvency law
*Employment Law
*Business ethics (not-tested)

Two exams, one group project
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is super passionate about his teaching and he concerns every students' learning pace. He is very willing to answer questions after class and provide assistance for us whenever possible.
Learning environment is fun and enjoyable, which makes law become a "not that boring" course. Charles often tell jokes and news during class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is lenient.
As long as you attended the lessons and jot down notes he wrote and talked about, you will have a clear concept of what to write in the exams. It is also important to look through the case analysis we did during lessons as they are the similar questions that will appear in exams. Cheat sheets are allowed in the exams and it would not be that difficult.

Projects part would also be quite important. Topics would be given randomly by slots. It would be better if you could provide a comprehensive picture of the whole topics and may provide legal case analysis if needed. Professor would provide information about what to include. However, it would be better if you could ask him the scope he would like to have in the project of the specific topics as some topics have already provided a suitable scope but some are just too wide.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload of this course is quite light comparative to other  business courses. The only assignment would be the group project and workload would depend on presentation and report.

For usual class, he would require us to have readings and case analysis but he would discuss with us in class time.

reviews.author: miks99
reviews.comment_content:
This course is an introduction to business law. There is no textbook for the course, all information is available on powerpoint. Attendance is not recorded.

The topics we learned:

- The Rule of law
- Copyright law
- Trademarks law
- Insolvency law
- Employment Law
- Business ethics (not-tested)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Charles has an interesting, quirky personality. Although his speech is fast-paced, he ensures his students have an understanding of the concepts through in-class and out of class Q&A sessions. He seems very passionate about his teaching, and cares a lot for his students.

Charles is fairly humorous kind of guy - often throwing in a joke or two about himself. The funniest I can recall him making girlfriend jokes in class. This contributed to an enjoyable learning environment.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was a bit harsh. Exams are not difficult. He allowed us to bring a cheat sheet for both the midterm and final exams - he stressed about not wanting us to memorise content as per se apply our knowledge.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload for this course if very light mostly throughout. Sometimes we were assigned readings and case studies, however he goes over them in the next class.

The only intensive part of the course was towards the end, when we had a group project presentation and report due.

reviews.author: ip
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture ppts are messy.
Many pictures rather than words are on the ppts. Imagine teaching law with pictures.
Other than pictures, she uses mostly hypothetical cases as examples on lecture ppts. I personally want to learn more from previous cases/ real cases happening.
Legal reasoning is not taught (eg arguing some possibilities using different legal principles).

Sometimes students ask her questions, and she replies that she does not answer hypothetical questions. It feels like she is not a subject matter expert.
reviews.comment_grading:
Got a B only.
Grading is not transparent.

3 MCQ Quizzes
The first one and third one were easy, mean was high. Second one was so difficult. She had to add marks for us as I suspect that the mean was fail or close to fail.
I got around mean for first and second one, got highest on the third one.

Final report
no mean was given, so I don't know although my marks were close to 90/100.

No marks disclosed for participation, and in-class writing exercise.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. In-class participation
There is post-class homework to be submitted on canvas almost every lesson. According to the prof, these are for students to get some participation marks even though they don't speak up during lessons. However, they are pretty demanding. Apart from your thoughts on examples discussed, sometimes you are asked to suggest some cases you have heard of and some examples. In addition, the post-class homework was not on the syllabus so we did not expect to do so much work every lesson.

2. Three quizzes throughout the semester
Make sure you know the concepts for contract law. There were many traps for quiz two.
A side note: MCQ quizzes are in hypothetical cases. The MC choices are usually some judgement such as "It is likely that side A can obtain compensation successfully due to blah blah legal principles".
In real life, the judgement usually depends on which argument and which evidence is presented, and how the judge thinks, but in this quiz, she is the judge so be careful and pay attention to the details of the scenarios.

3. In-class writing assignment
It is for you to familiarize with the legal writing style for your individual report. Pay attention to the IRAC style. As no feedback was given, no stats released, I don't have any tips for this.

4. Final report (individual)
You will be given a case, and a side (either plaintiff/defendant). You have to write a case brief, and suggest arguments and counter-arguments for your side. Brainstorming arguments can be frustrating. As it is based on a real case, your side may have lost in real life but you still have to brainstorm some arguments as it is said that "there are always possibilities that benefit a side" although arguing about these possibilities are not taught in class. In class, we learn from hypothetical cases that have definite answers.
